title: Hyperpallium
text:
The hyperpallium (formerly called the hyperstriatum or the wulst) is the destination for <a href="lemnothalamic%20projection">lemnothalamic projection</a>s in <a href="Bird">birds</a>. The projections as well as the <a href="granular%20cell">granular cell</a>s at the destination of the lemnothalamic projections to the hyperpallium are similar in morphology, <a href="electrophysiology">electrophysiology</a>, <a href="retinotopic">retinotopic</a> organization, and columnar organization to the <a href="striate%20cortex">striate cortex</a> in mammals. These avian granular cells are thought to have evolved independently in birds, as they do not appear in <a href="Reptile">reptiles</a>.
The projections originate in the dorsal <a href="lateral%20geniculate%20nucleus">lateral geniculate nucleus</a> and target three layers in the hyperpallium: the hyperpallium intercalatum, the hyperpallium densocellularis, and the nucleus interstitialis hyperpalii apicalis, with the densest projections being to the later two layers.
The <a href="Efferent%20nerve%20fiber">efferent</a>s of the telencephalic components of the lemnothalamic pathway project to the <a href="optic%20tectum">optic tectum</a> (equivalent to the superior colliculus), the lemnothalamic visual nucleus, as well as other optic tract targets.
The hyperpallium is observed to be large and well developed in <a href="Raptor%20%28bird%29">raptors</a> such as <a href="Eagle">eagles</a>, <a href="Hawk">hawks</a>, and <a href="Owl">owls</a>.
